div.p: ANTONY AND CLEOPATRA. A TRAGEDY. As it is Acted at the DUKES THEATRE.
Written by the Honourable Sir CHARLES SEDLEY, Baronet.
LONDON, Printed for Richard Tonson at his Shop 〈◊〉 Grayes-Inne-gate next Grayes-Inne- 〈◊〉 MDCLXXVII.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: AS a brisk Gallant dancing to his Glass,
Does here and there in nimble fleurets pass;
Likes every step, and wishes for a Ball,
Where he at once may shew his Parts to all:
So Poets (with the like conceit) undone,
Think that dull Verse which pleas'd 'em when alone,
Must have the like effect on the whole Town.
Our Poet all such hopes of Praise disclaimes,
Like a true Lover of the Sport, he Games,
And to come off a Saver only aimes.
Did he affect to be esteem'd a Wit,
Like you, he'd take an easier way to it:
Write Songs, and Prologues, shew 'em up and down,
And tear applause from every Fool in Town;
Make Love to Vizards in a Wit-like Noise,
Dull in his Sense, yet aiery in his Voice,
Catch at each Line that grates, and keep ten good,
With his damn'd Noise, from being understood.
'Tis well most Wits have something of the Mad,
Or where shou'd Poets for the Stage be had?
Cripples may judge of Vaulting he well knows,
Cowards of Courage; and of Verse and Prose
They that know neither; yet if too severe
Damning those Gifts of which they have no share,
Their Envy more than Iudgement will appear.
He none excepts, no, not his Enemies;
For those he hopes his Friends will counterpoise:
And spight of Faction on both sides he knows,
There is an honest Party in this House.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: OUR Arms an easie Victory have found
Over a Foe, in love and pleasure drown'd.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I am pleas'd we have Antonius subdu'd,
Yet rage to think a Roman was pursu'd:
Our souls did once our conquer'd Bodies loath,
And seldome did one World contain 'em both.
Yet now by hopes we're flatter'd to live on,
And with the Common Herd of Mankind run,
Crouching to Fate, which we by death might shun.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: His Army's yet entire, and on the Shore;
No Troops so far the Roman Eagle bore:
Armenian Kings they have in Triumph led,
And Parthian blood in ten set Battles shed:
Their General to the last they will defend.

sp.speaker: Mecoen.
sp.l: None can defend those, who themseves betray:
He with his Queen again will run away,
And leave 'em fighting, as he did at Sea.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Remember, Sir, the joy the World exprest,
When threatning Wars and Mischief, you redrest.
With a late Peace, which an Alliance ty'd,
And your fair Sister made Antonius Bride.
The like again you to the World may give,
If you content with half of it can live.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Against all strokes of Fate who can prepare?
That Match is half th' occasion of this War.
To him I did my dear Octavia give,
That Rome in peace, she might in Empire live;
That to one Emperor by blood ally'd,
And to the other by her Marriage ty'd,
She might all growing jealousie remove,
And be her self the Bond of lasting love.
But see th' unblest event; Antonius slights
That Tye, which even enemies unites;
And more than drunk with Cleopatra's charms,
He scorns both Roman-Love and Roman-Arms.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Love of our Country and our Interest
Is the true passion of a Roman Breast.
All other are Usurpers—

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: 'Tis most true:
Yet this vile Flame he never will subdue,
Which spight of time and of enjoyment lives,
And of it's bane miraculously thrives.
He thinks his life depends upon her eye,
As that of Plants does on the Sun relye.
The ignorant are learn'd, if she think so,
And Cowards even Hercules out-do.
At her request he Provinces bestows,
And no mans worth but by her stamp he knows.
Whilst my Octavia leads a Stepdames life,
And tends the Children of his former Wife,
Ungrac'd without authority or sway.

sp.speaker: Mecoen.
sp.l: The wrongs of that fair Princess, Sir, are great,
And rage in all, but in her self create.
What Hers forgives, our virtue shou'd chastise:
Mortals revenge the blasphem'd Deities.
And strait the Impious wretch in pieces tear,
Whom Heaven in clemency wou'd long forbear.
From equal pow'r how can you be secure?
And less Antonius never will endure.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Antonius worsted will no league refuse,
And give in peace what battle could not lose.
He may Octavia receive again,
And in his Bed and Empirie make her reign.

sp.speaker: Mecoen.
sp.l: Men leagues and peace in their distress embrace,
But keep 'em only till affairs change face.
Ambition's never safe till pow'r be past,
As men till Impotent are seldom Chaste.
Follow the blow, and doubt not the success;
But Fortune for her utmost favours press.
On petty Kings you trifling Conquests make,
Antonius brings you here an equal stake;
The World to be divided at one blow,
And Fate already has declar'd for you.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Men that have once an equal pow'r enjoy'd,
May see the Ballance chang'd, but not destroy'd.
He that is lessen'd to a Slaves degree,
Still conscious of the first equality,
Must hate the other, and himself much more.
Who ever saw a Captive Emperor?
With honour treat and yield perhaps he may,
But he can never like a Slave obey.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Peace we will offer, that he may refuse,
And the whole World his bloody mind accuse.
Thyreus knows the Queen: Him I will send,
Charge him that strait he in my Tent attend. Ex. Omnes.

div.head: Scene the Second. The Palace.
div.stage: Enter Memnon and Chilax, two Egyptian Lords.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: Was ever Queen like Cleopatra curst?
Of Egypts Monsters sure her love's the worst.
Where is that falshood does the Sex pursue,
Or are they only to their ruine true?
I said Antonius might have laid the Scene
Of War and Rapine further from the Queen,
That our week State shou'd to the Victor bow,
And humbly the Decrees of Fate allow.
She tells it him, and I must be displac't.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: 'Tis hard men for their love shou'd be disgrac't.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: No man may now his bleeding Country mourn,
Romans our Lords, and we their Slaves were born.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: The Times our honest Councels cannot bear,
And men their Thoughts must in disguises wear.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: Let Women, and Her Parasites seek to please.
Physitians should not flatter the disease.
Her dang'rous state 'tis Treason to conceal,
Which nothing but Antonius death can heal.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: 'Tis a rough Medicine she will never use,
And fatal were th' advice should she refuse.
We know his interest does her Councel sway.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: We this advice must privately convey,
Make her believe Octavius loves her too:
On that she will an easie faith bestow,
And in that hope what ist't she may not do?

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: 'Twere all in vain, and we our lives should lose,
Tamely and vilely laught at by our Foes:
Be Thieves and Rogues to execution led,
Let us die warm, and at an Army's head.
The Romans will not ever be thus strong;
Thousands as well as we for changes long.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: Let's silent wait the opportunity,
And by main force expel their tyranny.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: I love my Queen, and to rebel am loth.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I would but free her from Antonius pow'r,
And that once done, lay down my arms next hour.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Let us some plot against his life devise:
He's not our Prince; for publick good he dies,
And for our Country falls a Sacrifice.
But see He comes, and for his late disgrace,
His conscious vertue raging in his face.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How slippery is the Top of humane state,
And on exalted Heads what tempests beat?
Whom Iove will ruine he makes deaf and blind,
So that they hugg th' ill fate he has design'd;
I else could never have bold Roman Swords
Crowded and throng'd within these floating Boards.
Ships, whom the winds more than their Pilots sway,
Where eager courage for a wave must stay.
The Valiant cannot board, nor Coward fly,
But at the lust of the unconstant sky.
At land my Romans—

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Sir they bravely fought;
Tho rude in Ships and Sea affairs untaught.
Six hours they did a doubtful fight maintain,
Deserted by your base Egyptian Train;
And by your self, if I may be so plain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The just reproach has rows'd my Lyon heart,
Nor am I angry at the friendly smart.
I fled, Canidius, basely run away,
And fought for Empire below those for pay.
Of my new shame too much thou canst not say.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: They, who by Ships would such a Cause decide,
Did not for conquest, but for flight provide.
Pardon me, Sir, my bluntness must go on;
By barbarous fears and councels you're undone.

sp.speaker: Photi.
sp.l: We in Neutrality secure might wait,
And calmly expect an Emp'ror from Fate;
But in your quarrel half our Fleet we lost,
Led by that Roman courage which you boast.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: Our Ships with a promiscuous crowd were fill'd,
Neither in Battle, nor in Sailing skill'd.
Reapers and Ploughmen half ne'r tug'd an Oar,
Nor saw the foaming Sea but from the Shoar.
Must we be ruin'd and despis'd at last?

sp.speaker: Canid.
sp.l: Did we by land a victory forego,
That a vain Queen might a rich Galley show?
My Legions—

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Canidius no more.
I know they stood impatient on the Shoar:
Nineteen such Legions as might fate controul,
And fortunes wheel at their own pleasure roul.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: A loss at Sea let trading Nations mourn.
Victorious Romans to land Conquest born,
Trophies at Sea as much as gain despise,
Of which an Island is the highest prize.
The trembling world did to the Victor yield,
Crown'd with the Laurels of Pharsalia's field.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Since we have lost 'tis well the gain was small,
One lucky blow at Land recovers all.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Th' Enemy is already at our Walls,
And our distress for sudden Counsel calls.
Our Queen amazed at the Siege appears.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But yet her love is stronger than her fears,
Her Country she has made the Seat of War,
'Tis just her safety be our early'st care:
I will her Guard within these Walls remain;
And 'gainst the angry Gods her Cause maintain.
Whil'st you Canidius to your Legions hast,
Slight our defeat, their loyal hearts make fast
To our just Cause: our Enemies despise,
And for my absence some excuse devise.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Sir, I am blunt, unknowing to deceive,
I'le say you cannot Cleopatra Leave:
That you in her defence alone can fight,
And blest in love, the Roman Empire slight.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.l: What shall I do, shall I my Queen forsake,
And not her danger, I create, partake?
Caesar, this night, may Alexandria storm,
And all that lust or rage instruct, perform.
Her beauty may the Conqueror disarm,
And his success and love that beauty charm.
Her Subjects weary of the Wars, may rise
And make her blood their common sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: They say, their Queen in policy of State,
Should buy her Country's peace at any rate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They say! who says? Memnon you fain wou'd vent,
In others names, your private discontent.
I see a sullen fierceness in your brow
Which you wou'd put in act, if you knew how.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sir, I am known to love my Country well.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So they say all that purpose to rebel.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Some with your head would young Octavius greet,
And on those bloody terms a Peace compleat:
Under such Polititians Pompey fell
With tumults backt what may they not compel.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How shall they foes, who cannot tumults quell?
The giddy multitude, we must not fear,
But what we once resolve on, make 'em bear.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: 'Tis ill to discontent whom we must use,
And men fight best when they their party choose.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis chosen for 'em by their Soveraign;
And 'tis sedition in them to complain:
Maxims too popular you still maintain.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sir, my plain speech does no design contain;
'Tis the meer issue of my heart and brain:
If it offend—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It does, be gone.
Nor will I learn of you what's to be done. Exit.
When things go ill, each Fool presumes t' advise,
And if more happy, thinks himself more wise.
All wretchedly deplore the present state
And that advice seems best which comes too late.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: You loose your self in rage and have forgot:
Amintas, Deotorus— and the rout
Of vulgar Kings have meanly turn'd about.

sp.speaker: Canid.
sp.l: Pelusium by Seleucus is betray'd.
Some say the Queen did his revolt perswade.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Monster, such horrid blasphemy forbear,
Both were his own, the falshood and the fear.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Sir, I but speak the language of the World.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Henceforth be ever dumb that World and thou:
It cannot, must not, nor it sha'nt be so.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Nay if it sha'nt, I have no more to say.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Aside all passion and all heat Ile lay,
And cooly argue: what can be her end
There to betray, whom she does here defend.
sp.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmion, Iras with Seleucus 's young Son, Egyptians.
sp.l: But see the Queen: Heart! but this once stand fast— aside.
And I'le forgive thee all thy weakness past.
How can your goodness to a wretch extend?
Who all he lov'd so poorly did defend:

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: 'Twas not your life, but me, you cou'd not loose,
Love turn'd your back, not Fear upon your Foes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The timerous Deer, their female standing by,
Each other will to wounds and death defie.
Love gives short courage to the meanest soul,
The creeping things he arms, and winged fowl.
Yet overcharg'd with love, I lost the day,
And in my Mistress presence ran away.
Cover'd with shame, I fear to meet those eyes.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: To them you never were more dear than now:
A manly look over your sorrows throw.
The Captain of my Gallies I have try'd,
And for his cowardice the Villain di'd.
With him die all remembrance of what's past,
I my Caesarion have toward India sent:
This day Antillus to Armenia went.
What Merchant in one Ship wou'd venture all?
They may survive and so revenge our fall,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis well they're gone, their youth was useless here,
And we for them more than our selves shou'd fear. He spies Seleucus 's Son.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: See here the false Seleucus only Son,
On whom I beg quick justice may be done.
His fathers Treason might on me reflect
Shou'd I the Son from your reveng protect:
My love and honour, let his death secure,
The shortest doubt they neither can endure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: None dares be impious to that degree,
To lay on you the Villains treachery.
Now my revenge I cannot execute,
Lest I shou'd seem your virtue to dispute.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: You doubt me not I know, but others may,
Let his death take their jealousie away.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: She safely may the cruel offer make, apart.
Which she well knows Antonius will not take.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He must not die, nor is it true revenge,
When the offenders suffer by exchange.
The youth it seems is not Seleucus care,
Or our resentment thus he wou'd not dare.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Let him at least for an example die,
Princes invite, who pardon treachery.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Twere cruelty to kill the Innocent
For Crimes they neither knew, nor cou'd prevent:
I beg his life my Queen—

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: You may command
Or Life, or Death, at Cleopatra's hand.
We who but now might halfe the World command,
Are overthrown at Sea, besieg'd at Land:
Each hour the news of some fresh Treason brings,
From Faithless States or from revolted Kings.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let those Crown'd Slaves from out our Party go:
A Treach'rous Friend, will be a Tim'rous Foe.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: The Plains about are cover'd with our Foes,
Hiding the Earth, as when our Nile o're-flows.
Yet sate I in Antonius Courage rest,
As if that Heart he gave me fill'd my Breast.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: When Brutus this Octavius over-threw,
In a pitch'd Field I Cassius did subdue.
And turn'd the Fortune of that fatal day,
Which thus ungrateful Rome and He repay;
But here remaining I those Legions loose,
Which all commands but from my Mouth refuse.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: They ever us'd Canidius to obey;
May he not go, and my Antonius stay?
For you my Peoples love and more I lost,
Must I not keep what has so dearly cost?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ah Madam, you shou'd take the weakest part,
And help a Lover to defend his Heart.
Thô swounding Men with ease resign their Breath,
Their careful Friends still pull 'm back from Death.
You should my Lethargy of Honour chide,
And drive me thô unwilling, from your side.
Die at your Feet the meanest Lover might,
But in your quarrel the whole World shall fight.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: If I am Captive to the Romans made;
Surpriz'd in this weak place, or else betray'd;
Think not I'le live to be redeem'd again,
And like a Slave of my proud Lords complain.
At the first Dawn of my ill Fate I'le die.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O name not Death we ' l meet in Triumph here:
I'le raise the Siege e're you have time to fear.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: But then your Love, in absence, will it last?
Men think of joys to come, and slight the past.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Heart shall like those Trees the East does show,
Where Blossomes and ripe Fruit hang on one Bough.
With new desires, soft hopes, at once be prest;
And all those Riper Joys, Love gives the blest.
Courage and Love shall sway each in their turn,
I'le fight to conquer, conquer to return.
Seeming Ambitious to the publick view,
I'le make my private end and dearer, You.
This Storm once past; in Peace and Love we'l Raign,
Like the Immortal Gods, the Giants slain.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Moments to absent Lovers tedious grow;
'Tis not how time, but how the mind does go.
And once Antonius wou'd have thought so too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dearer than ever think not that I part,
Without the utmost Torment of my Heart.
Whil'st you perswade, your danger chides my stay,
Make me not cast me and your Self away.
How well I lov'd, you did at Actium see,
When to be near you I left Victory.
And chose to be companion of your flight,
Rather than conquer in a distant Fight.
Press not that heart you know so well, too far,
Our Fortune will no second frailty bear.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: The truest Misers choose to sit about,
And tell their wealth: but dare not trust it out.
I know as well as you, 'tis fit you go,
Yet what is best I cannot let you do.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: For my attendance I some few will take;
All other Romans of your Guard I make.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: If you must go, it quickly shall appear,
My love sought this delay, and not my fear.
When you attaque, we'l sally from the Town,
And blood instead of Nile our Plain shall drown.
We'l in the midst of Caesar's Army meet,
And like Bellona I my Mars will greet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wou'd Goddesses themselves to me endear,
In Cleopatra's shape they must appear.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: My heart can danger though not absence bear,
To Love, 'tis Wax, but Adamant to Fear.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Mine has such Courage from your Firmness took,
That I can almost bear a parting look.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Take it; and each unto their charge make haste.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Our hardest victory I hope is past.

div.head: Scene the First. The Town.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: EMpire and Glory both farewell: Come shame,
And shed thy Venom on Antonius Name:
Wither the Lawrels on his Brows and teach
The World to scorn its most inglorious Wretch.
Forsaken in the choicest hour of time,
My hopes and resolutions in their prime.
Honor, my Queen and I Dictator made,
And all his rough Commands cou'd have obey'd.
Love for a while, we purpose to dethrone,
As Mariners in Storms their Sails take down.
Can Romans thus their General forsake?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: They urg'd want of Provision and of Pay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Both which had been redrest without delay:
Th' obliging Queen—

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Whom you may thank for this—
Their general Discontent at her was lowd:
But Souldiers are a rude uncivil Crowd.
Play'rs and Minstrels, Singers and Buffoons,
Are the great Instruments and Props of Thrones.
I my old Legions to your Aid have brought,
Firm to your Side, not tainted in a Thought—
They say Photinus in the Camp was seen,
And that he was imploy'd there by the Queen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: At a revolt so strange I am surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Pray Heaven it were not in the Town devis'd.
Your upright Nature stoops not to Descry
The low and subtil ways of Treachery.
Thô you may fail, She can't; Beauty will find,
Victorious and young Monarchs ever kind.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your honest meaning does your life protect:
Presume no more her vertue to suspect.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: May I not say Photinus is a Knave?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tax not the man, unless good proof you have.

div.stage: Enter Photinus pursued by six Villains,

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Those two you must destroy, and me disarm.
Ah, Sir, from Murtherers defend your Life:
See with my blood, they have begun the Strife.
sp.stage: They draw, two of the Villains fall, the other run.
sp.l: The Gods a Guard for Vertue still provide:
Courage with Treason seldome doth reside.
Th' are fled and you unhurt—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am:
But say, Photinus, whence these Villains came.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Just as I left the Throng—
They set upon me Crying this is He,
That with Octavius lets us not agree,
Antonius Friend, and his own Countreys Foe;
And strait that word was followed with this blow.
Some of the popular faction set 'm on,
Who think to govern all if I were gone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis most unlucky these were Kill'd out right,
Of their whole Plot we else might gain some light.

div.stage: Phot. stabs one lying on the ground, he mutters out

sp.speaker: 1. Villain.
sp.l: Photinus is a Villain ....

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: See their spight ....
Even at their Death, which I will thus requite— Can. interposes.
Why wou'd you save from my just rage so impudent a Slave?

sp.speaker: 1. Villain.
sp.l: Photinus set us on:

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Unheard of villany ....
My self to Kill, they did conspire with Me!
But great Antonius is himself too just
Me on a Murd'rers malice to distrust.

sp.speaker: Canid.
sp.l: Slight not too much the words of dying men,
They who hate truth before will speak it then.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: My constant zeal and firmness to your side,
So oft in Council and in Action try'd,
This accusation cannot but deride.
What is't a Murth'rer missing of his blow,
In his last rage would not both say and do?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Who dares die,
And the just Gods provoke with such a lie?

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: He that dares basely Kill, what dares he not,
No Crime a Murtherer cou'd deeper blot.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Yet to that crime ingratitude may add.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: You speak as of my guilt you wou'd be glad.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My friends, let this untimely discord fall.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Although much wrong'd, at your Command it shall.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: I wish, Sir, to my Souldiers you wou'd speak,
And let 'm know how well their loves you take.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I go: their Faith shall so rewarded be—
The rest shall soon repent their treachery.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Had they fought well their danger had been small,
Cou'd they not fear at first or not at all?
Curse on all middle ways: Courage enough
When once engag'd, can only bring us off.
But the next blow by fate shall be my own,
And I'le strike home for Iras and a Throne.
My person is ungrateful, I well know
It was contriv'd for use and not for show.
Besides I 'm old, that too when I am great,
She may have the Ambition to forget.
This gentle Maid all other ways have try'd,
Hopeless of Love, I'le now attempt her pride.
But see she comes, and charming as new light,
Appear'd to the first Mans amazed sight.
You hear how Drums and Trumpets fill the Air,
And for a Scene of Blood our Minds prepare.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: 'Tis Love, vile Love whence this Disorder springs.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: The tender Parent of the frightful'st Things.
Yet blame not Love, when to it's object fixt;
It only harms when with Ambition mixt.
When raging Winds raise Tempests on the Main,
The gentle Brooks creep mildly through the Plain.
'Tis only to the Great these Storms are known,
Photinus passion fears your scorn alone.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: What is this Love, we never can exclude?
But whatsoe're we talk of, 'twill intrude.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Of Storms the Seaman tells, of ploughs the Hind;
Lovers in such discourses ease their mind.
'Tis the glad business of young Hearts, the pain,
The old, for their presumption must sustain.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Is't a disease beauties infection spreads?
Pray does it seize you in your hearts or heads?

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Sweet Innocence! it enters at the eyes,
And to the heart like subtle lightning flies.
When Lovers meet it is all extasie,
And when they part again they more than die.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: How chance that I have scap't this mighty ill?
I gaze and stare at every thing my fill.
The Wise, the Handsome, and the Brave, I love,
Yet feel no pain at all when they remove.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Passions lye yet within your tender breast,
Harmless and weak as Eagles in the Nest:
But Love hereafter on your heart will prey.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: If ever any one escap't, I may.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: 'Twere most unfit you shou'd, Nature does still
Provide some soveraign thing for every ill.
For Beauties wounds their kindness is the cure:
Scorpions who cou'd without their oyl endure?

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: If I have hurt you 'twas against my will.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Your Charms not like a Foe, but weapon, kill.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Their farther ill effects I will prevent,
And of what's past, though innocent, repent:
I'll go where you shall never see me more.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: That must not be, from you whom I adore.
Absence is raging pain, presence a joy;
Which will at least voluptuously destroy.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Wou'd you not have me go nor stay! what then?
This Love I see makes errant Fools of men.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Stay gentle Iras; learn to love of me,
How easie were it, cou'd I charm like thee.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Does no man else adore me as you do?

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: None ever did; I'l place you on a Throne,
A Scepter may for pers'nal wants attone.
Beauty and Youth, your Sexes glories are,
In men they soon decay, or not appear.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: I did not know you were a Prince disguis'd:
At your new Majesty I'm much surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: I am no King.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: How then shall I be Queen?
O I could strut with Cleopatra's Mein.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: The Roman Empire can a Crown bestow.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Such gifts may be Antonius overthrow.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: So let 'em be.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: But what, he gives you, Rome
Will take away, if Caesar overcome.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: My hopes, sweet Innocence, in Caesar lye,
And e're I reign Antonius must dye.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: You have but the Reversion of a Crown,
And e're he dies how old you will be grown.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Your youth a while may for such glories wait,
But you may trust my Love to urge his Fate.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Must I then marry you,
or be no Queen?

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: I'm not so wither'd, nor are you so green:
Nay Charmion will accept what you refuse,
And when she reigns your peevishness accuse—
It works—

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: No no! my self I'll have you first—
To see her Queen I should with envy burst.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Will she then promise to love me alone,
When I have plac'd my Iras on a Throne?

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: I will do any thing, to be a Queen;
I could love one whom I had never seen. Enter Messenger.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Madam, the Queen much wonders at your stay. Ex. Iras.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: She's gone, she's gone, and I me-thinks have more
A thousand times to utter than before,
So inexhaustible's a Lovers store.
To her Ambition I her Love must own;
But Fate her youth, my age will have it so.
How false a Joy in that fair Sex he takes,
Whom once the hope of equal love forsakes.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Mecoenas see strict discipline they keep
Through the whole Camp, that neither wine nor sleep
Betray us to surprize: thô peace seem near,
Wise Pilots at the Port a tempest fear.

sp.speaker: Mecoen.
sp.l: Great Sir, your Souldiers find they have to do
Not with a rude unarm'd and barb'rous Crew,
But Romans like themselves, in Conquest bred,
And next your self, by the best Captain led.
Their jealousie of Fame and Love for you,
Will make 'em any thing forbear or do. A shout of joy.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Antonius Legions newly are arriv'd,
And through the Camp are with loud joy receiv'd.
Tir'd with his impotent and distant sway,
They now, Great Sir, will you alone obey.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Then vanish all his hopes, and all my fears,
In my whole sky of Fate, no Cloud appears:
That one black corner did a tempest threat.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: You much are to Photinus care in debt:
Him in the Camp, when I arriv'd I found.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Yee Gods! why am I to a Villain bound?
Tell my new friends, I their arrears will pay;
A Roman Emperor they still obey.

sp.speaker: Mecoen.
sp.l: Antonius now will any Laws receive,
What from weak Foes we do not take, we give.
Demand the Roman Legions yet behind,
And that his pow'r to Asia be confin'd.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: The man was once my Friend, my Brother still:
What are these thoughts that wou'd ambition chill?

sp.speaker: Mecoen.
sp.l: Forget that name he has deserv'd so ill.
The spoil of Egypt will the War defray;
For a meer peace Rome will repine to pay.
Him brother, let Aegyptian Princes call,
He has no Interest in your blood at all.
Since the best Ty he slights, and in her place
Does a less fair Aegyptian Queen embrace.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Pernicious Counceller that does foment
A War, all but the Parthians wou'd prevent.
My Wrongs shall never thy Ambition hide,
I'le tear the Masque of pity from thy pride.
I thought thee once deserving thy great place,
Of Tuscan Kings sprung from the glorious race.
But thou art false, cruel, and bloody now,
That open hatred thou durst never show.
To my dear Lord, does still in malice lurk,
And on this dire Occasion seeks to work.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Sister, your Husband I would but reclaim,
And make him worthy of your virtuous flame.
His present life does his past glory stain,
He makes a Queen the Partner of his raign.
The Roman Empire he does much deface,
And with the Spoil adorns her foraign race.
Arabia where the Nabatheans live.
And part of Syria he did lately give.
To their new issue one he stiles the Moon:
To name the other, he profanes the Sun.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If he has given much, he conquer'd more:
His valour, for his bounty, found the store;
And pardon somewhat on a Sisters score.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: The names of Emperor and Queen they scorn,
And like immortal Gods themselves adorn.
He does for Bacchus, she for Isis pass,
And in their shapes, the wond'ring Crowd amaze.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: To Gods of their own honour leave the Care,
Since they both Jealous and Almighty are.
I fear so high you'l my concernments press;
You'l break on that you never can redress.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: I understand no Riddles, but he shall
Do my Octavia sudden right or fall.
The rest I cou'd with small excuse forgive:
But under this affront I cannot live.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: You say his other faults you cou'd forgive.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Empire's our real quarrel, but I must Aside.
Her virtuous Mind with no such secret trust.
I could—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Then that pretence I'le thus remove and dy: Stabs her self. Mec. interposes.
Still more inhumane must I then remain,
The cover of your Pride and Lust to reign.
Thô I were dead you might your ends pursue,
But let me vanish from the painful view.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: Not for the World such virtue shou'd not dy,
But be intire translated to the Sky.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: I Sister your late rashness can forgive,
So you henceforth will promise me to live.
Mecoenas see remov'd all means of Death,
Let Nature and not rage conclude her breath. Ex. Caesar, Agrippa, &c.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Peace to the World and my unhappy Lord,
My Brother but for you wou'd soon afford.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: Condemn not actions till you know their end,
But mine perhaps will then but more offend.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I know you'l say 'tis brave to rule alone,
That my great Brother wou'd become that Throne.
And raising him you in proportion rise,
But still remember there are Deities
Above you both, just, pow'rful, and wise.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: Ambition never overturn'd my mind,
I am already more then I design'd.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Why do you then the general peace oppose;
'Tis Avarice or Ambition makes Men foes.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: I Madam wou'd some marks of courage show,
And what I durst for my great Master do.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Romans of courage need no other proof,
Since to be born a Roman is enough.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: 'Tis truth, but yet—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Some unjust pique you bear,
My dearest Lord, you cannot well declare,
But good Mecoena's; for such once you were;
T' obstruct this Treaty for my sake forbear.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: 'Tis for your sake alone, it must not be.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If it be good for Rome, regard not Me.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: Y' are Sister to my Emperor and Friend,
My utmost care, must your concerns attend:
I do not as you think confusion seek,
Nor keep I to your Lord a secret pique:
But if this Treaty be confirm'd to day,
I must at Rome, and you in Asia stay.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: It is the part of the whole World I'd chuse,
And gaining Him, what is't I care to loose.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: Ah Madam, seem less virtuous or less fair,
Who can behold you and not vengeance sware.
Such suffering goodness will mankind ingage,
And on Antonius pull their publick rage.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: This to the Sister of your Emperor;

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: This to the only Beauty I adore:
Beyond my patience you have rackt my Breast,
And my deep guilt at last must be confest.
I love you, Madam—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: My next request you'l then not disallow,

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: Speak it, and I a blind Obedience vow.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Let me then die for I have liv'd too long,
And heard of Love in my Antonius wrong.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: Not in his wrong! I'le the reversion wait,
And live like Heirs in hope of an Estate.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Your word is past recall. My Death I claim.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: From me who both your Guard and Lover am.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I not the stroak, but means of Death require:
By my own hand I noblest shall expire.
Will you then promise to promote the peace.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: You offer poison, to my known Disease:
But from those hands I nothing can refuse.
I'le ruine all my hopes, so you will live:

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Yes, I will live, but not an hour survive.
My dear Antonius him you must preserve,
If ought you from Octavia would deserve— Ex.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: Whom, whilst he lives I never can enjoy,
And if he dies she will her self destroy.

l.hi: I am undone; obey or disobey!
I needs must perish, but may chose my way.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: THe Asians now with double Taxes prest,
His slothful Days and drunken Nights detest;
Buffoons and Players chiefly have his ear:
He dares not the free tongues of Romans hear.
To marry Whores to Fencers is his sport,
And with their Issue throng his loathed Court.
" Now lewd Cytheris has a greater Train,
Than his own Mother or his Wife maintain.
From such a Foe as this what can we fear!
In whom all symptoms of lost pow'r appear.

sp.speaker: Mecoen.
sp.l: The flatt'ring Greeks his easie nature praise;
But on the rest he heavy burthens lays.
In drunken Bounty, for a riotous treat,
He gave his Fav'rite Cook a spacious Street:
Men say no hour dares move without its Feast,
Which is for their fantastick pallats drest.
Now must the rising Sun their Riot view,
Which the next day prevents the Evening dew.

l.hi: In every draught they some rich Gem consume,
And spend a private Fortune in one Room.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Empire, of pains and virtue, the slow fruit,
How ill dost thou with vice and riot suit?
Cinna was bloody, Marius unjust,
Tarquin and Appius raging in their Lust:
Lucullus was luxurious, loud his ease,
Thus on each man his single vice did seize!
But all these faults are in Antonius met.

sp.speaker: Mecoen.
sp.l: His Court with Asian Flatt'rers is fill'd,
And Lying Greeks the only Servants held.
These serve the turns of riotous delight,
Whilst Romans only are thought fit to fight.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Example is a living Law, whose sway,
Men more than all the written Laws obey.
Princes of all men therefore shou'd take care,
How in their manners they the Crowd ensnare.
But above all his dotage on the Queen
Employs my wonder: was it ever seen
A Woman rul'd an Emperor till now?
What Horse the Mare, what Bull obeys the Cow?
Nature that Monster Love does disavow:
In all her kinds only fantastick Man
Finds ways of folly which no other can.

sp.speaker: Mecoen.
sp.l: He that will vilify the pow'r of Love,
In the first place let him our Gods reprove,
Who oft their heavenly Mansions have forsook,
And the mean shapes of Birds and Beasts have took,
To pursue Mortals in an amorous way,
And form their glorious Image in our clay.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: The God that lov'd, what Nymph yet ever rul'd?
He was again a God, his Lust once cool'd:
Had womens will our good or ill procur'd,
The World had never half so long endur'd.
The high embrace fill'd all their spacious thought,
And proofs of kindness were no farther sought.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Th'unable sure, the ugly, or the old,
First in affairs of Love, made use of gold.
Then Princes to out-bid 'em threw in pow'r,
Now heart for heart's the Traffick of the Poor.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Women should 〈…〉 like idle Passengers,
While the tall Ship 〈…〉 steers.
Wisdom, high Courage 〈…〉
If o're the Wise and brave 〈…〉
And this Antonius conduct ha 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: 'Tis time the insur'd World we should redeem
From a mans sway so lost in her esteem.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: What is success in Arms if Conqu'ring Rome
By Troops of Asian Vices be o'recome.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: To set all right I must be absolute;
My least commands None daring to dispute:
Rome's desp'rate state can never find redress,
But from a pow'r as able to oppress;
Whilst for the publick good my pow'r I use,
Seeing my end Men will the means excuse.
Th' Omnipotence of Gods, who thinks too great,
Since men below they with compassion treat.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: But envy does all mortal pow'r attend:
Men fear the Means, and still suspect the end.
He that can hurt, who answers but he will:
Men pass in fear by sleeping Lyons still.
Empire is safest moderately great,
And death unseen does on Ambition wait.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: He that can do no ill, can do no good,
And if in one, in both may be withstood.
The actions of a Tyrant I abhor,
But as things stand I cannot want the pow'r.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Our Laws the art of ruling best contain;

sp.speaker: Mecoen.
sp.l: Fools find it there, wise Princes in their Brain.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Pow'r long possest few Princes care to use,
But give it up for others to abuse:
From Phoebus self the World no hazard run,
But cou'd not bear one day his Vent'rous Son:
He through new wayes the flaming Chariot drove,
And all was fear below, and fire above.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: I to no Phaeton will the reins commit,
Nor in inglorious ease a moment sit:
Ile see the Common-wealth no mischief take,
And do and suffer all things for her sake.

sp.speaker: Mecoen.
sp.l: Rome on your vertue leans her aged head,
As old Anchises on Aeneas did,
And thinks she may with 〈…〉 you.
Factions at Home, 〈…〉.
You, whom the 〈…〉 oes hold,
Bolder than Youth, and 〈…〉 Old.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: The name of Common-wealth is popular,
And every Caesar may his Brutus fear.

sp.speaker: Mecaen.
sp.l: Romans that barb'rous Murder so reveng'd,
It shews the thoughts of a Republick chang'd.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Men die of Agues, too much heat or cold,
And others grow ridiculous old. Ex. Caes. Oct. Mec. manet Agrip.
The thoughts of humane chance should make us bold.
Ile seize the Empire, which Ile die or hold.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Born under Kings our Father freedom sought,
And with their blood the Godlike treasure bought,
We their vile issue in our chains delight,
And born to freedom for our Tyrants fight. Exit. Agrip.

div.head: Scene the Second. The Palace.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: For what Sir, must we then prepare?
Thyreus! does he bring us Peace or War?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: He offers Peace, but upon terms so high,
At the great rate I'd not an Empire buy:
My former gifts I meanly must resume,
And give accounts of all my act to Rome.
My faithful friends from their Commands remove,
And place such as the Senate shall approve.

sp.speaker: Canid.
sp.l: True friends displac't will pardon your distress,
And thô your pow'r—

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: A Pageant pow'r and Empire but in show—
True Empire only those great Souls enjoy,
Who can in what, and whom they please employ,
And without leave from Rome a Crown bestow,
Exalt a Friend, and trample on a Foe:
This by your Love and Arms I once attchiev'd,
Nor will be of it but by Arms depriv'd.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Ambition is the Dropsey of the Soul,
Whose thirst we must not yield to but controul.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Some Drudg of State may a less pow'r esteem,
And ruling many, let a few rule him;
Mean Slave to them, high Tyrant to the rest,
With fear and pride at once defile his breast:
By Hercules I won't, if any here
Think that a Course too desp'rate I steer,
Let him retire, and his own fears obey.

sp.speaker: Canid.
sp.l: The Gods well know my fears are all for you,
And your most daring thoughts shall find me true:
It is not Caesar, nor our blow at Sea,
That to these terms incline me to agree;
But 'tis the love of Rome which you have lost,
And that your Ryots here and Loves have cost.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Caesar and I you know were never friends,
And only hung together for our ends:
Yet in his Cause this Tongue an Army rais'd,
And made Rome hate that deed she late had prais'd.
Brutus and Cassius felt the deadly sting;
And all to make Octavius more than King.
So blindly did I act, so little see,
Into the dark Decrees of Destiny.
The Common-wealth for him I overthrew,
Now in effect he claims my Empire too.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: The Shell he leaves, the Kernell takes away,
You, Sir, must him, as others, you obey.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He wou'd a sway pretend over my Love,
And teach my free affections where to move.
To my embrace his Sister I must take,
And my best Queen ingratefully forsake.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: That Sister is your Wife.

sp.speaker: Ane.
sp.l: So let her be
From past engagements, present Love, set free.
Hymen is but the Vulgars Deity ...

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: O my Antonius! how I fear this Peace!
And must I to Octavia yield my place?
I love you so, that very sound wou'd kill,
And leave you free the promise to fulfil.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Were I to gain the Empire of mankind,
And for that pow'r, Eternity assign'd:
I cou'd not to the hateful change submit,
Nor my best Queen so barbarously quit.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: But your Octavius loving, young, and fair,
And such a Rival! how can I but fear?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Her Hymen never did a Moment please,
The hard Condition of a needful Peace:
From every part I saw the growing storm,
A sudden shelter in her arms I took,
Which when 'twas over I again forsook.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: And can you for My sake a War sustain?
Her Brothers friendship and Her Love disdain?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: All hearts a like, all faces do not move,
There is a secret Sympathy in Love:
The pow'rful Loadstone, cannot move a Straw,
No more than Jet, the trembling Needle draw:
Your Beauty only on my Heart can act:
All other ways, it is in vain attaqu'd.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Sure of this War I am the meer pretence,
How can our Love, to Rome give such offence?
She shou'd revenge the Ghost of Crassus slain,
And haughty Babel level with the Plain,
But let in Egypt, Love and pleasure reign.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Rome like her Eagles, did on Rapine thrive,
I am the first that taught her how to Give.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: What y' have presented me or plac'd on Mine,
I to that griping Senate here resign.
I never did the gifts but Giver prize:
Some new pretence of War let 'm devise:
All but your self I for your sake can quit:
For you I did my Crown and Fame forget;
And can you now weigh 〈…〉 ly what it is fit

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Turn my best 〈◊〉, from her charming Tongue,
'Tis hard to think such Beauty in the wrong:
Yet if you don't, we are for ever lost.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have resolv'd: to Caesar I will send:
If he his Grace will to the Queen extend,
And let the Crown upon her Sons descend.
I'le kill my self, and rid him of his Foe,
If not, the last extreams I'le undergo.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: What Roman will the hateful Message bear?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Let us intreat, we may at Athens live,
And tast what joys a private Life can give:
Leaving our greatness and our pomp behind,
We shall in Love sincerer pleasures find:
But whether am I wrapt? fond thoughts be gone,
And melt some tender Virgin of low race,
You are below a heart that wears a Crown,
Where Life, Love, all must to renown give place.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Souldiers, when old we from the Wars discharge,
But Fate her Drudges never sets at large:
The higher place they fill, the greater Slaves,
Princes have no retirement but their Graves,
My equal pow'r this Caesar cannot bear,
His Souldiers want my Provinces to share:
Unactive Lepidus he laid aside,
And will no longer now the World divide;
Whose doubtful Title must by Arms be try'd.
But see Thyreus here ....
He has some Message for your private Ear,
Which I without a jealous pang can bear.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: She is a woman, Sir, and when y' are gone,
By Caesars Offers may be wrought upon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Jealous! yet truly honest. 'Tis strange how
In thy plain mind such wild suspition's grow,
I will return before their Conf'rence end,
But on her Love entirely I depend. Ex. Ant. Canid.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: Madam! my Master's gracious as he's great,
See's how y' are forc't t' allow this short Retreat,
To his proud Foe, and does himself excuse,
That Ayd perhaps you cou'd not well 〈◊〉:
The Ruines of a 〈…〉 Emperor,
In her own Kingdom may a Queen o're pow'r.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I first was summon'd in Romes haughty Name,
E're I into Antonius presence came.
Brutus and his I was accus'd to Aid,
But soon acquitted and her Ally made;
Since in Antonius I have Rome obey'd.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: If an Ally of Rome you shou'd disclaim,
The Man, whom she does Foe and Traytor name.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Those very Titles She Great Iulius gave,
And yet anon, obeys him like a Slave.
On the Success of War, her Voice depends,
The distant Foes she stiles the present Friends.
Let others from Antonius fortune fly,
I will support or in their ruine lye.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: His Souldiers have another sence declar'd,
And are to storm this stubborn Town prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Base Mercenary Souls that fight for Pay,
To morrow Kill, whom they defend to day:
But Princes Minds on Springs of Honour move,
And what can they not do, wound up by Love?

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: If not your Self, your harmless Subjects save,
They neither love so well, nor are so brave.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Despair shall make those heartless Villains bold,
While by worse fears, the fear of Death's controul'd.
I'le Rome provoke beyond all hope of grace,
Then in their Arms, they must their safety place.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: They'l sooner take those Arms up and Rebel ...

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Antonius Souldiers will such Tumults quel.
The People ever discontented are;
Their Crouds were made to be the food of War: Ex. Phot.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: Caesar is pleas'd—
You shou'd keep all the Realms of which y'are seiz'd;
Some little to deserve this you must do.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Desert propos'd me from a mortal Foe?

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: Give us but entrance in the dead of night,
We all will spare who are not kill'd in Fight;
Like Caesar, Cleopatra shall command,
Antonius falls into a Brothers hand.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Who will revenge the scorn his Sister finds;
Are these your deep, your generous Designs?

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: You but precipitate the event of War,
And by that act a Sea of Blood might spare.
I have a step beyond my Orders made,
Which were but to propose not to perswade.
But who can see such Beauty in distress,
And not the utmost of his thoughts express.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: In Fates whole scope I fear but one event,
And that your self with honour may prevent.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: What is it, Madam? will you hear me swear,
You trust your secret to a Lovers ear,
One that has long, and privately been so.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Sir to make Peace, you were from Caesar sent,
But make not Love, thô but in Complement.
If Caesar take this Town by Fates decree,
Swear to inform, what he will do with me—

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: 'Tis not resolv'd, soon as I know I will ...

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Then sound him dayly with your utmost skill.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: But is this all? I was in hope to serve,
In some design that might your Love deserve.
This for your meanest Slave I had perform'd.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: 'Tis all of which I care to be inform'd—

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: My Offers, Madam ....

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: They are such as show,
Romans but ill of th' hearts of Monarchs know.
But on your promise may a Queen rely?

div.stage: Enter Antonius, Canidius unseen, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: You may: but doubt not Caesars Clemency;
Your Crown and Person, thô provokt he ' l spare,
Conquest and Ruin will respect the Fair,
What may n't such Beauty hope, nor is it new,
That he who rules the World should bow to you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By Heaven, at Complements; I'le pause a while,
And see this subtle Scene of Womans guile.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: My Fates worse Face you will not then disguise,
I can behold it with undaunted Eyes.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: And may it prove as charming as your own;

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I fear you will forget me, when y' are gone.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: I swear upon my Knees and by that Hand:
Whos's every touch, my Soul leaps up to meet:
Let me once more th' inflaming Bliss repeat.
Like the first drop which Men in Feavours tast,
It to a deeper draught but makes me hast.
Thus starving Men, think every thing a Feast,
Whil'st some with tastless plenty, ly opprest:
O that I were Antonius but one day!—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Slave from that posture thou shalt never rise,
But be my Wraths immediate sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, your Sword you shall not rashly stain;
What hopes of Peace Embassadors once slain?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ambassador of Love the Villain came;
And 'mongst affairs of State he vents his Flame,
He Kist her Hand, some charming Message sure,
At least of half my Empire, She's secure.
Which she perhaps must with my Life repay,
These are the Bargains made when I am away:
'Tis more than Madness to believe that you,
False to my Love, are to my Empire true,

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I false to you!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By Hercules you are: and had I stay'd,
None knows the faithless answer you had made.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: What is it that so strange Antonius finds?
He kist my Hand in taking of his leave,
'Tis a respect that Queens from all receive.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The eager Kiss, no Lover can mistake,
It extacy and sudden rapture spake,
Those of respect are of a colder make:
Ye Gods! he swore by't perhaps endless Love,
Or that he wou'd your Mediator prove.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Ask him! His offers I have all refus'd,
And yet of falshood live to be accus'd
By you, for whom I suffer, is this just?
One minute, brings long faith into Distrust.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Minutes may ruine what in Ages rose,
Like Thunder, Love in instants overthrows.
He has disturb'd me. And he shall be whipt,
Canidius see he instantly be stript.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: If thus you trample on all Roman Laws,
What Roman is there that will own your Cause?
The Law of Nations too does this withstand,
To any thing that's brave I'le lend my hand,
But stir to no such infamous command:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Seize the bold Traytor.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Will you have him flead.
Say but the word, this minute he is dead.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There's a true Servant to his Masters will,
Whom I condemn, he questions not to kill,

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: With this affront if thou dar'st glut thy hate,
No pow'r on earth can save thy falling state:
Caesar will take revenge—

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.l: Away, away ....
And my command see strictly you obey.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I do not know that I a smile misplac't.
Frown'd where you frown'd, and where you lik't I grac't.
Not Wealth to Misers, Honour to the Brave,
Health to the Sick, or Freedom to the Slave
Cou'd be more welcome than you Love to Me,
Then think how felt, the cruel change must be:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What Change?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: How can you ask; while this distrust appears?
Distrust, the first decay of Love in years.
What we desire we easily believe,
Love on the smoother side does still deceive.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your Lover shall be whipt, and as you bear
That, I shall think you criminal or clear.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Not to the Man, but to his Character,
Such an affront I wish you wou'd forbear.
It is a deed that might amaze the Sun,
And by the rudest People yet undone:
In all the Travels of his fruitful light,
He has not met so barbarous a sight;
Ambassadors are sacred next the Gods,
Above your Axes plac't as well as Rods.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Observe how, least I change his punishment,
All ways of my revenge she wou'd prevent,
He may not die ....

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Nor shan't, unless your hate,
All human Laws resolve to violate.
Then kill me first.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: The Cities up, the Souldiers Mutiny,
And all— long live the good Thyreus cry.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: My Romans take and charge 'm instantly.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: What they demand, perhaps you'll not refuse.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: How ' er their Insolence I'll not excuse.

sp.speaker: Canid.
sp.l: Good Sir, abroad you know we want no foes,
This inward strife methinks we might compose:
Octavius work our selves, let us not do.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: My People Sir, I hope you'll not destroy,
Whose lives I for your service, wou'd imploy.
Photinus say their Queen bids 'm begon,
And trust our Love, what's fitting shall be done.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Your Romans, Sir, joyn with th' unruly crow'd,
And to defend th' Embassador, have vow'd:
They say a Roman never shall be whipt,
While Sword or Spear a Roman arm can lift.

sp.speaker: 1. Mess.
sp.l: They have by this the Castle Walls broke down,

sp.speaker: 2. Mess.
sp.l: And set Thyreus safe without the Town.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Draw up my Guards, if I have yet a Friend;
This Tumult shall in death of Thousands end.
What must Octavius conclude of me?
If whom I once imprison, they set free.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: They have done right by chance, excuse 'em fort;
Tempests sometimes drives Ships into the Port.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The Rable is a thing below my hate,
But my own Romans I will decimate.

div.stage: Enter Lucilius Captain of the Rout.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: For what is done, I singly am to blame:
The rest but on my call and credit came.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: What mov'd thee too't: Old Ruffian, thou shalt dye;
In thee I'll punish the whole Mutiny.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I saw my General about to blast,
By one rash act, his life and Glories past.
Th' unconstant Rabble to my side I gain'd,
And spight of him, his Honor have maintain'd.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A Roman.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: No more?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In Brutus Camp some small Command I bore:
Subdu'd by Arms, since by your kindness won,
I am resolv'd your utmost fate to run.
If my late service grieve you, take my head;
The common path of Love I never tread.
Brutus, to save my self, like him I shap't;
So fell I in your hands, and he escap't.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Lucilius?

sp.speaker: Lucilius,
sp.l: The same my Int'rest command,
Antonius shall both rule my heart and hand.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Discharge the Rabble you have us'd in this. They shout.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: They humbly sue you'll pardon what's amiss.
They are return'd, and now with shouts of joy;
They beg you woud their Swords and Lives imploy.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Most willingly, just Heaven, what am I,
Whom the rude People, teach Humanity? Ex.

sp.speaker: Caesar,
sp.l: MY Offers scornd! Ambassadors abus'd!
Yet he of Pride unjustly is accus'd.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: Thyreus was ill chose, he long has been
A secret Servant to th' Aegyptian Queen.
What if I went with terms more moderate;
I, who am less Obnoxius to his hate.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: This Offer now the danger grows so near,
In a man less known, shou'd take for fear.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: His Insolence no longer I defend.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: See here the Challenge he thinks fit to send. Agrip. reads.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: In single Combat let our Fencers fight:
With Armies, Emperors dispute their right.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Like him, I Roman blood would gladly spare,
And to a Combat would contract the War.
My youth, and unfoil'd strength, may Conquest claim
Over this Shadow of a mighty Name:
Now prest with Age, and with Debauches worn,
Th' unequal Combat I not fear, but scorn.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: He like an aged Oak in Autumn shows,
From whose dry Arms some Leaves each minute blows;
One King or Ally, still forsake his side,
His Empire ebbs like a declining Tide.
Have patience, Sir, he of himself muk fall,
Who in despair does for the Combat call.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: To a brave Death I'll open him the way;
See an Assault be made without delay.
I at my Armies head shall soon appear,
And if he dares, he may engage me there.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: O Brother! if that name have yet a Pow'r,
And be not lost in that of Emperor:
Pity my sad estate, since I alone
On both sides mourning, can rejoyce on none.
The World divided in their wishes stand;
My self alone stab'd through on every hand.
A Brother here! There must a Husband fall;
On the just Gods I know not how to call!
No chance of War can with my mind comply;
But I must weep at eithers Victory.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: If I o'rcome, your Husband I will spare.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: He will not spare himself, I more than fear,
Shou'd he prevail, th' Egyptian Queen will sway;
Whom you, and I, and he, must all obey.
His am'rous heart must execute her will,
And whom she frowns on, in Obedience kill.
You to Ambition must a Victim bleed,
And from my hated Title to his bed,
Must Cleopatra in my Death be freed;
And haughty Rome acknowledg a vain Queen,
Or be of Civil Arms th' endless Scene.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: He doth all terms of Reconcilement slight:
There nothing now remains but that we fight.
He's now a meer soft Purple Asian Prince;
And Rome his Empire has disown'd long since.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Ingrateful Rome! but most ingrateful you!
Can you forget whom Cassius overthrew?
Who first to Rome a Parthian triumph show'd,
And the long Pride of that great Empire bow'd?
Who the first Caesar made, revenged his death,
And fixt that Empire, which he did bequeath,
On you almost unknown: Where they receive,
Base Natures hate; and Love, but where they give.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Go serve th' Aegyptian, learn to dress her head;
Your slighted Love, and your neglected Bed
Can you forget; and fulsomely pursue
The Man with kindness, who despises you?
I shou'd my self scorn fawning Beauty too:
'Tis as absurd, as if the Gods shou'd sue.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Wives (like good Subjects, who to Tyrants bow)
To Husbands though unjust, long patience owe:
They were for Freedom made, Obedience We,
Courage their vertue, ours is Chastity.
Reason it self in us must not be bold,
Nor decent Custom be by Wit controul'd.
On our own heads we desperately stray,
And are still happiest, the vulgar way.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Who ever did such Moral Nonsence hear?
My Sister sure is turn'd Philosopher.
But we Antonius Pride will soon pull down;
This hour shall give me his whole lifes renown.
I the long trade of Fame disdain to drive;
But to the Top will at one step arrive.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Since then my pray'rs and tears can nothing gain,
In the Foes Camp no longer I'll remain.
The Arms I hate, my presence shall not grace;
Antonius Cause I'll openly embrace.
To Rome I'll go, and all thy acts disown;
Make thy Ambition, and thy Falshood known
To every Roman of the Sword and Gown,
Till th' art more hated far than Cateline,
Then Scilla, Marius, or the Tarquins Line.
Some will for Freedom, some Antonius fight,
And against Thee both parties I'll unite;
Amongst thy Foes I like a Spark will fall,
And to a sudden Flame convert 'em all.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: You wou'd not sure my Love so ill repay.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Your Love! your Pride and endless Thirst of sway.
To gain my friends, my Quarrel you pretend,
But universal Empire is your end.
Rome's once great Senate now is but a name;
While some with fear, and some with Bribes you tame.
Men learn at Court what they must there repeat,
And for Concurrence, not for Council meet.
At least all such as think of being great,
They blindly labour at their own ill fate,
And dig up by the roots the tottering State.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Against Antonius Riots they declare,
And I at their Command but wage this War.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Dull Long-gown Statesmen you may feel that Sword
Which thus you whet against my injur'd Lord.
When Caesar wills a Law, for all your rules,
It will be better taught in Camps, than Schools.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Your fears distract you, or you needs must see
Your hopes of happiness depend on me.
'Tis my success must make Antonius find
The dire effect of an unbridled mind.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Who ever did an Emperor reform?
Scarce Heav'n it self can that great Task perform.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Heaven chooses me the fittest instrument,
And on that glorious Task I'm wholly bent.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Is't thus Mecoenas, you promote the Peace?
But you ne'r meant, and promise but to please.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: All that I durst, I have already said:
I urg'd him till he thought I was afraid.
But where such Beauty, and such Goodness fail;
What other Intercession can prevail;

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Mecoenas, I no Complements expect
From one, who does my first Commands neglect.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: Men that like me have giv'n their Passions vent,
Are never after held indifferent.
Hatred, or Love, pursues the bold attempt;
It meets with a return, or with contempt.
I fear the latter is Mecoenas lot.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I charge you, never entertain me more
With that false Love which hath so little pow'r.
Your breach of Word, I easily forgive,
I'm free, and am not now oblig'd to live: She weeps.
Nor will I long, the first attacq survive.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: A sound like that, what Lover can indure?
I'll move once more, shou'd I his hate procure.
Ah Sir, your weeping Beautious Sister view;
Then if you can, her Husbands life pursue:
Such softness might an angry God disarm,
And from his hand, the brandisht Thunder charm.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: What means Mecoenas softned in her tears?
Another Man he to my eyes appears.
Where is that Soul bids me be Absolute,
And the dissenting World with Swords confute.
Move forwards still, and spread my Conqu'ring Arms,
As far as Cinthia lights, or Phoebus warms.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: I can no more, you your own Cause must plead;
I wou'd, but can't against my self perswade;
Tho unsuccessful my endeavours were,
It was some Merit to obey so far.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: The Enemy preventing our attacq,
Does a fierce Sally on our Forces make.
Our formost Troops the warm ingagement shun,
And to Canidius his Old Souldiers run.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Then be your Tent your Prison for a while. To Octavia.
Now let us seize the Lyon in our Toil.— Ex. Onmes.

div.head: Scene the Second. A Wood.
div.stage: Enter Antonius, Canidius, Photinus, at one door, Agrippa, Thyreus, at the other, Fighting.

sp.speaker: Antony.
sp.l: Turn back Thyreus; 'tis Antonius calls;
The Queen now sees thee flying from our Walls.
Think on that shame, and it must warm thy heart,
And do not from a single Rival start.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: A Thought like that, were all Mankind my Foes,
Wou'd send me headlong amongst all their Blows.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He dies of Mine that dares to interpose.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: Of Mine he is my basest Foe that does. They fight, Thyr. falls.
Love, thou at last art just, and having made
My Life a Burthen, help'st me to unlade:
If he o'recome, Let Cleopatra know,
She must to Rome in Caesars triumph go.
So now my promise to the Queen is paid,
The first and last Command I ever had.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then all my Fears were false.

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: False as my hopes,
Or the short vigor which my Being props.
The Queen was Cruel and thy Sword was Kind.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou didst attempt her Villain:

sp.speaker: Thyr.
sp.l: Yes, I did,
And with my dying Breath I boast the Deed. Dies.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What words fit to appease her shall I find?
Jealousie for ever from my Soul remove,
Thou magnifying Glass to erring Love;
Thou Viper like, dost thy young Teeth employ,
And wou'dst that Love, which gave the Birth, destroy.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Charge you Canidius with your Troops, whil'st I
Against Antonius self my Fortune try.
Here is the utmost bound of thy success,
The Ocean may as soon his limits pass,
As thou this spot of Earth whereon we stand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You speak as you had Thunder in your hand,
The Gods! Heaven! Hell and Fate at your command;
Which if thou hadst I'd not one step retire:
But one by one, their Prodigies wou'd tire. Caesar is beaten back.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: You must not stay your fortune to pursue,
Agrippa's got between the Town and you;
Which Stratagem when Cleopatra found,
She Sally'd out, and is incompast round.
Photinus stays behind to awe the Town,
And keeps those of the pop'lar Faction down.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Queen ingag'd! To her relief lets fly,
Death has more Charms near her, than Victory.
Me in her Cause, the Legions that withstand,
Must fall like Corn, before the Reapers Hand.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Must we again a Victory forgo;
This Queen was born to be our Overthrow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What is't you mutter? Follow me or dy.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: My Life you'd sooner want behalf than I:
Take it, for 'tis to me an hourly pain,
Follies of Friends are nothing to the slain.
But whil'st I live, methinks you shou'd pursue,
Retiring Foes and Victory in view.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I cannot stoop to argue, but Obey;
And till my Queen be safe, let Conquest stay.

div.head: Scene the Third. A Wood.
div.stage: He discovers Agrippa 's Army, and the Queen taken.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By Hercules she's tane! So have I seen the Dove,
Under the Pounce of eager Falcons move:
O! that I were my self the Dart I throw,
For now, all other Motion seems too slow.
sp.stage: Ant. rescues the Queen, Charges through Agrippa's Army. Agrip. Retreats to the Town.
sp.l: Augures and Entrails, Boys and Quails you ly!
And I henceforth your Omens will defy.
Call'd by his Name, may such still prosp'rous be,
While thus the Gods give Victory to Me. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Photinus as within the Town.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: They are ingag'd by this: now is the Time,
And all things seem propitious to my Crime.
Let Fools the Fame of Loyalty divide;
Wise men and Gods are on the strongest side.
The Town is wholly left to my Command,
To make 'em rise I need but slack my hand:
They'r prone to Mutiny. Their Queen they hate,
And shew all signs of a distemper'd State. They shout.
But hark already they are up and roar,
Like an high Sea that scorns its wonted Shoar.
But see fair Iras whose bright form in Tears,
Like Sun-shine mixt with sudden Rain appears.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Photinus! Oh the Queen! The Queen is gone,
And we that stay behind are all undone.
The Pallace flames; Memnon and Chilax rage,
And all the Egyptians on their side engage.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Fear nothing Madam never was a time,
When Innocence and Beauty were a Crime:
Each shout you hear, your Greatness does advance:
Nor is this Mutiny, th' effect of Chance.
But my design—
Through Craggy ways we for a while must tread:
But gentle Iras to a Throne they lead:
Ah! Cou'd I make you Kind as well as Great,
Photinus happiness were then compleat.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: All other Forms I'le study to forget:
And think how much I'm to your Love in Debt:
Antillus is a young gay handsome Man,
Yet to please you, I'le hate him if I can.
He still like you lies squeezing of my hand,
Hangs o're my Neck, and from me will not stand.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Ye Gods! She loves and knows not yet disguise!
The happy Name, flasht at her youthful Eyes.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: The Manly Gown when he did first put on,
He was more gaz'd at than Caesarion:
But for all that I will not love him tho,
'Tis so long since I have forgot him now ....

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Our Serpents though new born are poysonous still,
And Women ne'r so young have Craft and Guile.
She has forgot him! Oh that I cou'd Her!
Too plain, but yet too strong I see the snare.
I got my Rival to Armenia sent,
His Name returns and ruins my content.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: You seem disturb'd—

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: False and inhumane ....

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: What are you mad?
What is it I have done! What have I said?

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Thou hast for ever rob'd me of my rest.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: By all my hopes to reign I love you best.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Ay there's your love to me.
But that for him how ill you do contain?

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: For whom? I understand you not, be plain.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Why for Antillus? Your young Gay Delight.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: May I not name, but I must love him straight?

sp.speaker: Pbot.
sp.l: The Works soon done with Wind and Tide they move;
Whom equal Years and Thoughts dispose to love.
And to say truth I stand condemn'd within,
That I did ever an Address begin
To you, whom Beauty and such Youth adorn:
I prest with Age, for Toil, not Pleasure born:
And every way the Object of your Scorn.
Go to Antillus! Fly into his Arms,
And meet with equal heat and equal Charms.
Whilst my ambition I henceforth pursue,
And recompence those Joys I lose in you.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: He wou'd not have me if I wou'd, I fear,
He's great and may expect a Kingdoms Heir.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: She fears he wou'd not have ... Oh just Heaven!
I to the last extremity am driven.
She'l ask me sure anon to joyn their hands.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: All thoughts of me your self you have resign'd,
And I may now to whom I please be kind.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: All thoughts of you! I cou'd resign my breath
With half the pain ....

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Some other Maid you purpose to make Queen,
And I but flatter'd, and abus'd, have been.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: My Love, a fierce Convulsion did endure,
And in the pain I talkt I know not what;
But rest for ever of that heart secure,
Where too much Love did the short storm create.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: The Castle is beset, and all have vow'd,
To stain their Weapons in your treacherous blood.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Step in a while: They that will rise must wait,
And at each Throw assist their lab'ring fate. Ex. Iras.
Let 'em all enter, no resistance make,
I can die gladly for my Country's sake.
sp.stage: Enter Memnon and Chilax with the Rabble.
sp.l: What is't my honest Countrymen demand?
You need not ask with weapons in your hand.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: Thou hast thy Country to a lasting War betray'd—

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: And therefore for thy death prepare.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Who! I! alas I but my Queen obey'd,
And both were of Antonius pow'r afraid.
Like you I wisht an opportunity
When Egypt was from Roman Forces free:
That we might then with Caesar make our peace.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Now Fate presents it, this occasion seize,
In our Queens absence you the Town command;
Egypt requires her Freedom at your hand.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: The City Gates against Antonius shut,
So thou wilt put thy meaning out of doubt.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: But then our Queen—

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: She is Antonius Slave,
And merits amongst us nor Throne nor Grave;
This once perform'd, be thou our General,
If not, like a faint Slave unpitied fall— Offers to run at him.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: I'l do unforc't what ever you require,
But now you bind me to my own desire;
I ever thought Antonius Cause unblest,
I did his Riot loath and Loves detest:
So we did all I think: and 'twere unjust,
We shou'd defend, who still abhorr'd his lust.
Let Pimps and Parasites his Battels fight,
Buffoons, and loose Companions of the night,
Male-Bawds, and let that goatish drunken Herd
Which made him odious, die, to make him fear'd.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: Antonius now (at Rome) despairs of all,
And seeks to crush our Egypt with his fall;
But he shall find that some of us still wake,
Who nothing fear, and all dare undertake.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Let's man the Town with all the Force we have,
Keep out Antonius, and our Country save:
Caesar will hold us Enemies no more,
But call in Friends and Allyes as before.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: For us the people do in throngs declare,
Tir'd with the danger and the charge of War.

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: I'm brav'd here by Canidius at each turn,
And with revenge and rage like you I burn:
The mighty Charge I greedily accept;
Your Town shall be with Faith and Courage kept.
In your disgrace, believe I had no part,
But honour'd your free Tongue and honest Heart.

sp.speaker: Memn.
sp.l: How we were all mistaken in this man? Exeunt.

div.head: Scene the Fourth. The Gates being shut.
div.stage: Enter Antonius, Cleopatra, Canidius, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: How well my Queen doth this one act reprove
My needless Jealousie, and shew your Love?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Her! whom you not esteem, why wou'd you save?
But thô unjust, Antonius still is brave.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I not esteem you! by the Gods I do
As much as Love—

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: No my Antonius! No!
You think me all that can a Queen disgrace,
Lighter than Woman, and than Man more base.
How cou'd I else forsake you in distress?
Or could Thyreus in a moment please.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: It was the raging Feaver of my Love,
And strongest Natures, strong Distempers prove:
Forgive it Madam, as my Loves excess.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Had Caesar su'd, I had his flame disdain'd;
And cou'd you think another entertain'd?
When the whole World shall to his Fortune yield,
My Heart against your Foe shall keep the Field.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: On me so thick your obligations fall,
I must subdue that World to pay 'em all,
And make proud Rome acknowledge you her Queen;
Your Glory does demand no less a Scene.

sp.speaker: Canid.
sp.l: 'Tis very fine, here's all the Sense he has!
His Legions, Empire, all are in that face!
I do not think he knows he is besieg'd,
But quite undone, talks how he is oblig'd!
Pray, Sir, do you consider where we are,
If we stay long we shall have Caesar here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Were he in sight I'd not one word forbear
Till I did guiltless to my Queen appear.
Thyreus dying—

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Have you kill'd him then—
I shall be hateful to the Race of men.
To Cleopatra it is death to speak:
On him she loves, she a swift War does call,
And those she looks on, by Antonius fall.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: He clear'd your Vertue with his dying Breath.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: You stain'd it in the manner of his death.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Lovers like Misers cannot bear the stealth
Of the least trifle from their endless wealth.
I saw him kiss your hand, for that he dy'd:
And shou'd had he Ten Thousand lives beside.
You seem not pleas'd with my revenge enough.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: It was too rash, and for his crime too rough.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: T' attempt the spotless Honor of my Queen,
Is such a Crime, as it is death to mean.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: He shou'd have liv'd, if that he lov'd indeed,
My Scorn all other Torments might exceed:
His life had been but one continued pain,
And mine but one long Act of my disdain:
But now all means to clear my self are lost;
You can but think me innocent at most.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: I from that Viper such an Oyl have wrung,
As heals that Love which he before had stung:
Since from a dying Rival's mouth I hear,
His hope was as ill grounded as my fear:
He call'd you most Ingrateful as he dy'd;
Confess'd his Passion, and accus'd your Pride:
What stronger demonstration can be thought?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Could nothing I might say, the like have wrought?
Then vain is all I've suffer'd, and have done:
My slighted Fame, and my endanger'd Throne,
Can nothing weigh; and 'twas Thyreus grace,
That I was clear'd! Antonius held me base.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: O say not so! My Love of its own strength
Had overcome that jealousie at length:
To him indeed I owe my speedy Cure.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Are you for ever from relapse secure?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: I rather will believe all that is strange,
The whole Sex true, than that my Queen can change.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: The Town is lost, your Romans kill'd or fled,
And false Photinus does the Traytor head:
Memnon and Chilax in bright Arms appear,
And for Octavius Caesar all declare

div.stage: Anto. Canid. appear with their Army under the Walls and find opposition, some that go near are kill'd.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Treason before, and Enemies behind;
In such a choice 'twere equal to be blind.
I know not which I shou'd attacque the first;
I'm only sure of all: Delay's the worst.
Storm then the Town with all that we can make
E're Caesar see, and this advantage take.
Safe at a distance here my Queen must stay, Charge without.
While we with blood and slaughter force our way.

sp.speaker: Canid.
sp.l: It is in vain, these Barb'rous Villains dare
Not hope for the fair Quarter of a War;
And are turn'd desperate.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: We are alike,
Desperate with them,
When for the whole both Parties strike,
